status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. Verizon Fios posted your street. We have told permittees when they post a street in Boston they must show up for the dates indicated on the sign. Parking is a premium and we acknowledge that is is frustrating moving your car and not having anyone show up. We understand that sometimes construction has unforeseen issues like equipment breakdowns, asphalt plants not available etc. resulting in not working the days posted. However we have told the permittees they must change the dates on the signs to reflect the new work dates. We have instructed Verizon to pull down the signs and repost 48 hours before they want to perform the work, and to make sure they work the days posted. We apologize for the inconvenience you incurred. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

Every Saturday night, extremely loud music that sounds like it's coming from an outdoor concert begins at around 10 PM and continues well past midnight.  I'm in the west end and can't tell where it's coming from, despite looking at local concert listings. Same playlist and same time, every Saturday ... and the noise is a terrible nuisance!

The yearly epidemic of fireworks has started in Fields Corner.  Neighbors all over the area (but with heavy concentrations on Bloomfield and Dakota Sts) are nightly setting off increasingly long shows of amateur fireworks.  By 7/4 these will turn into an all night affair with incredibly loud, percussive explosions making the whole area a war zone.  
I have taken to leaving town the week of Independence Day, because my 4 year old daughter is so traumatized by this experience.  She gets upset whenever she hears any loud, unexpected sound ever since our first summer in the neighborhood 3 years ago.
I have in years past made many phone calls to the local police precinct, but get told they don't have the resources to stop the fireworks.  That may be true, but I maintain that this phenomenon would not be tolerated in more affluent parts of the city.  Fireworks are illegal for a reason.  They are a major fire hazard for the whole neighborhood and ruin our quality of life. Please help.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) does require utility companies and private contractors to install utility ID Tags. Paving is done in two phases.  In the first phase, the permittee places the hot mix asphalt base course.  The second phase the permittee comes back and places the final top course. Tags are required on the top course, not the base course. What you observed was the excavation left in the base course of asphalt. Once the top course is placed, the required number of tags will be installed. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

The tree in question is under warranty for two years from the date it was planted. All new trees are inspected every summer during the warranty period to make sure they are alive and healthy. If they are found to be dead they will be placed on the warranty replacement list for the contractor to replace in the following planting season.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for contacting Boston 311. We apologize about the past experience you've had using our service that was not satisfactory. Would you mind providing more details regarding the case that was handled in an untimely manner? In regard to the noise complaint, we ask that they are reported to the police to ensure the fastest and most efficient response. The Boston Police Department monitors and enforces noise complaints because they  are the only City department that has the equipment and resources to do so. If you are uncomfortable calling 9-1-1 for a noise complaint issue, you can place a call to 3-1-1 and we will relay the information to 9-1-1.  If you have any other questions or concerns, please feel free to call Boston 311 and ask to speak to a supervisor. Thank you.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. Eversource Electric had an oil leak on its transmission line. This transmission line is critical for the power supply to South Boston. Eversource has been working ever since to rectify this critical situation. This was not planned work. They totally understand and regret the tremendous impact they are having on the residents near this work. That is why Eversource sent out flyers to the neighborhood explaining the situation. They have had to place stationary work zones along the route of the repair which included H St, K St, and now East Second. This is to protect the workers and the public. They have police details and Eversource Supervisors who are allowing residents access in and out. Public Works and the Transportation Department also understand the inconvenience to the South Boston residents for this necessary work and we also apologize. There is a 24 hour project hotline number 617-541-7634 if you needed something addressed right away.If you want to reach out to Eversource to discuss this matter further you can email John Hoey at John.Hoey@eversource.com. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Outdoor construction is best done without frozen pipes and soils, and snow on the ground. We requested the contractor hold off on the start of construction until the play equipment (the major lead time elements) were shipped to reduce the downtime we often encounter.  The play equipment is arriving on site and the contractor makes visible progress daily when weather permits.  We are doing our best to limit the amount of time the playground is offline, while trying to improve the few play spaces available to Roslindale residents. If you have any questions, please contact the Project Manager Cathy Baker-Eclipse at 617- 961-3058.  Thank you.
